subSections.title: Translingual
Alternative forms
subSections.text: * In mainland China, the top component is written {{l|mul|⺶}} (the {{l|mul|丿}} stroke is not split into two strokes). * In Hong Kong, Japan and Korea, the top component is written {{l|mul|𦍌}} followed by {{l|mul|丿}} (split into two separate components). * A {{w|CJK Compatibility Ideographs|CJK compatibility ideograph}} exists at U+FAAA for the alternative form used in Taiwan that resembles the form used in Hong Kong/Japan/Korea that is written with 12 strokes.

subSections.title: Usage notes
subSections.text: This character is not found in the authoritative {{w|Kangxi dictionary}}. See glyph origin below.

subSections.title: Related characters
subSections.text: * {{l|mul|[[著]]}} ''(Preferred form used for {{w|traditional Chinese}} in Taiwan)''

subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
Corrupted variant of {{l|zh|著}} ({{l|zh|艹}} → {{l|zh|䒑}}; {{l|zh|日}} → {{l|zh|目}}). Recorded as an unorthodox form ({{zh-l|俗字*}}) in the {{w|Tang dynasty}} orthographic dictionary ''{{w|Ganlu Zishu}}'' {{w2|zh|pref=《|干祿字書|suf=》}}. <!-- Refer http://dict.variants.moe.edu.tw/variants/rbt/word_attribute.rbt?educode=A03506-015#18 -->

Later dictionaries such as the {{w|Ming dynasty}} {{lang|zh|《字學三正》}} and {{w|Qing dynasty}} ''{{w|Zhengzitong}}'' {{w2|zh|pref=《|正字通|suf=》}} recorded the glyph as {{lang|zh|⿱𦍌⿰丿目}}.
